Tai Chi Kinect

Inspiration

Physical therapy

What it does

Allows the user to practice Tai Chi with the help of a robot instructor.

How we built it

We used the Microsoft Kinect to capture video data of us performing tai chi moves in order to train the classifier to recognize the individual motions. The scene was built with Unity terrains. An animated instructor was created by matching video data to animations.

Challenges we ran into

The Kinect is very finicky. Animations were also difficult because we have not really worked with them before. Getting the different technologies - Unity, Kinect, Myo to play nicely with each other.

Accomplishments that we're proud of

Live animation of humanoid model based on Kinect motion capture.

What we learned

Animations with Kinect.

What's next for Tai Chi Kinect

Built With

  • c#
  • javascript
  • unity
  • kinect
  • myo
  • machine-learning
  • animation

SnapThat!

Inspiration

We were inspired by an app called photo math which took mathematical equations from pictures and translated them into text. This made us think of applying object recognition software in other ways where they would benefit people's daily lifestyles. After a brainstorming period during breakfeast, SnapThat! was born.

What it does

The user takes a photo of their at latest meal which is run through the Clarifai api to return the identity of the food. Then, it is plugged into an array to find out the nutritional content, which is returned to the user.

How we built it

We built this through Android Studios with code from the Carifai api.

Challenges we ran into

At first, we had difficulty connecting a phone to Android Studios to use as a testing device. In addition, we ran into several problems finding a useful api to use as a nutritional database. Many were simply too advanced and non-user friendly.

Accomplishments that we're proud of

We managed to build a professional app GUI to back up our code We also created our own nutritional database, albeit limited in it's scope.

What we learned

The majority of our team had no knowledge of Java, the main language for our code. In fact, one member had no prior programming exposure whatsoever. However, at the end of the hackathon, each member definitely advanced their knowledge of not only Java but also computer science as a whole.

What's next for SnapThat!

Future aims include allowing the user to post their pictures directly onto Instagram and keeping track of their daily calorie intake, as well as recommending various workout plans and food choices based on prior data.

Presentation

Built With

  • java
  • xml
  • android-studio

TollGO

TollGO

I love going on roadtrips with friends, and being college students, money isn't always there. Splitting the cost of a road trip is easy until you have to account for tolls. You'd need to go to a separate website for every state you're travelling through, figure out which exit you get on the highway in that state and which exit you get out, and then sum it all together. This is where TollGO comes in.

TollGO was made to help people figure out how much they have to pay in tolls before they go on their trip.

JAJA Bill Spliter

Inspiration

Too many times I've seen tables of 10 people trying to split a check after the dinner with the basic calculator on the phone for 15 minutes. Other "tip calculator" apps only add and divide, which doesn't provide much functionality. This inspired this project which is to make the best user experience for bill splitting.

What it does

Takes in the information of the check and tells everyone how much to pay!

How we built it

All of our team members were very excited about the idea despite the fact that it's the very first android app we're building. We decided to use android studio and then basically utilized google and stack-overflow to implement our vision.

Challenges we ran into

Understanding the errors in a new developing environment is very frustrating. At one point we had so much errors in the project that we had to revert it back to a previous state!

Accomplishments that we're proud of

We made a complete and functional android app. We also showed teamwork and shared responsibilities. Before yesterday we never sat together at the same table, but we've all contributed to this project in unique and different ways. We are amazed of how much we can accomplish as a team in such a short time.

Team members

(In alphabetical order) Andrew, Project oversight and quality assurance; Aniqa, Lead UI designer; Jinqiu, Coding and algorithms; Joseph, Research and Development

What we learned

How to build an android app, but more importantly, to get ourselves into a complete unfamiliar environment.

What's next for JAJA Bill Spliter

More functionalities to be added to the app in the future such as advanced bill split (dish by dish), bill sharing (receipt to all) and a UI revamp.

  • xml
  • android-studio

Aventor

Inspiration

Tinder and the feeling we get sometimes when we're bored at home with nothing to do

What it does

When the user opens Aventor for the first time, they're prompted to select from a list of event-based interests such as "meetups," "parties," "games," and "spoken word." Using the Eventbrite API, Aventor queues up local events near the user for the user to swipe through. The most relevant events are shown first. Each card shows a picture, the title of the event, and a short description. The user can swipe through the events and choose to either "pass" the event or save the event to a calendar.

How we built it

We only have pictures/sketches of the project.

Challenges we ran into

We were considering making a web based app through a framework such as Meteor. However, we know barely any Javascript, JS frameworks, or JQuery. So, we could not build it.

Accomplishments that we're proud of

Coming up with an original idea that has not been implemented according to our research.

What we learned

Through the QueensHack workshops, we learned a bit of JavaScript, Phaser.io, and a bit about JavaScript frameworks as well as using Git for project management. We also learned what we need to do from this point onward to make our app a reality.

What's next for Aventor

Learning Javascript and implementing a basic version of it and then porting the application to different platforms.
Created and designed the outline of Aventor. Made the design of the app interesting for younger audiences as well as the older generation.
I worked on a creative and outgoing description for the app, one that may relate to the audience. Kept it humorous without deviating from the purpose of the app.

It's aMAZEing

Inspiration

We wanted to create a game where most of the map would be hidden from the player. We also wanted to have a player vs. player element in our game to create some intense moments. We found that a maze would work perfectly since being able to only see the walls directly around you creates a claustrophobic feeling and fear what might be around the corner. We also wanted to implement a game mechanic from a popular game mode called Gun Game. If you were able to exit the maze, you would advance to the next maze. First player to complete the last maze wins. However, if your character is destroyed, you will be demoted back down to the previous maze.

What it does

This is a web based game that is meant to be played by multiple players on different computers. The object of the game is to be the first player to complete all the mazes. When the game starts the player can only see what is directly around him. While trying to solve the maze the player can pick up pieces of light to increase their vision range. When the player completes the maze, they will progress to the next maze and their light will be reset. However, if another player kills them they will be demoted back to the previous maze.

How we built it

We built it using p5.js library.

Challenges we ran into

Originally we were trying to build the program in Phaser.io, but we found that it wasn't working well for creating the game we wanted. Our biggest challenge was creating a maze with collision detection.

Accomplishments that we're proud of

We are proud of getting the the random maze generator to work with our maze box objects. We are also proud of checking for collision detection that doesn't require scanning every box object. Instead it only detects and checks the 8 boxes that surround the player. We are also proud of creating the mask that surrounds the player since its a pretty neat trick.

What we learned

We learned how to randomly generate a maze. It is a very interesting algorithm. We also learned how to move a player around a maze without having to scan every single box.

What's next for It's a-MAZE-ing

We really want to bring our game onto a server and add player vs player elements. We also want to implement level progression as well as "special" light pickups. We also want to balance the players with more light with players with less light. Players with less light would have a shorter delay on a dodge mechanic since higher light level players will have the advantage of sight.

Built With

  • javascript
  • p5

fairShare

Inspiration

At the hackathon we were puzzled trying to find the best way to divide a pizza slice evenly. We came up with an idea of an app that helps you decide how to cut food on even pieces.

What it does

You tell the app the dimensions of your food, it decides how to cut it for you.

How we built it

We used javascript and html. In the future we plan to use image recognition API to make the app even more professional.

Challenges we ran into

The initial idea was to make it a phone app that interacts with camera and plans out where to cut the food on a photo. Soon we realized that time constraints of a hackathon force us to go for a simplified version.

Accomplishments that we're proud of

beautiful UX design

What we learned

we learned how to use github efficiently!!

What's next for fairShare

use API to take picture of food recognize the shape and the app gives the best possible cutting method. perhaps we can also use augmented reality technology to make it even better. there is a lot we can do to improve this app in the future.

Wallet Wise

Inspiration

We all have money issues so why not have an app that can regulate that problem.

What it does

It links to your bank account to find out how much money is inside your account, shows your previous expenses as well as your disposable income. Ideally this will be used to build a basic financial understanding for young college students as well as adults who are carefree when it comes to budgeting.

How we built it

Our lead programmer built this app on android-studio coded with Java.

Challenges we ran into

Unauthorized security access and safety for our users.

Accomplishments that we're proud of

Just managing to finish the app in time is a huge accomplishment. Another accomplishment would be to have our app working.

What we learned

Financial issues in the real world by researching.

What's next for Wallet Wise

Hopefully we will be able to add encrypted usernames and passwords for security purposes.
